Award.AwardTitle: UNS: Resolving the Dynamics of Particles in Turbulent Wall-Bounded Flow: DNS and Experiments

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
CBET - 1510154
PI: Longmire, Ellen

Turbulent flows containing discrete particles occur in many environmental and industrial processes related to climate prediction, energy production, and environmental conservation. In environmental flows, particles may be natural (plankton, spores, sediment, or dust) or pollutants (plastics, exhaust or fallout precipitates). These flows are difficult to understand and predict due to the wide range of turbulence scales in the fluid as well as the complex physical interactions that occur on the scale of the particle diameter. The goal of the proposed research is to advance experimental and numerical simulation capabilities to resolve particle/turbulence, particle/particle, and particle/wall interactions in turbulent flows near solid surfaces where these interactions often determine particle deposition and resuspension rates, mixing, and transport.

Complementary experiments and direct numerical simulations will investigate particles released into liquid turbulent boundary layer flows in a controlled fashion. Single moving particles and pairs of colliding particles will be considered where the particle diameter exceeds the smallest turbulence scales and where the particle Reynolds number is significant. Experiments will employ three-dimensional tracking of discrete particles combined with time-resolved tomographic particle imaging velocimetry to quantify translation and rotation, slip velocities, and spatial velocity gradients experienced by individual and colliding particles. A novel conservative overset grid method for unstructured grids will be developed and applied to simulate and fully resolve flow and stresses on moving particles in turbulent flow matching the experimental conditions. The results will be applied to assess existing particle/force coupling models and to suggest model improvements. The project will involve graduate and undergraduate researchers. The project team will work with teachers and students at a local elementary school to spark interest in science and engineering and to develop hands on physics and engineering activities that can be incorporated into the required science curriculum.

Institution.Name: University of Minnesota-Twin Cities
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF MINNESOTA

ProgramReference.Text: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

POR.DRECONTENT:
Turbulent flows containing discrete particles occur in many processes related to Grand Challenges in climate prediction, energy production, and environmental conservation. These flows are difficult to understand and predict due to the wide range of turbulence length scales in the carrier fluid as well as the complex physics that occurs on the scale of the particle diameter. The goal of the proposed research was to advance both experimental and simulation capabilities to resolve key particle interactive effects in turbulent wall-bounded flows.  Key outcomes of the investigation included development of novel experimental and simulation techniques that allowed investigation of these detailed effects.  In addition, the techniques were employed to elucidate surprising aspects of the particle dynamics.

Intellectual Merit:

On the experimental side, we developed a method to fabricate magnetic, spherical particles of controlled density that could be held in place on a bounding surface and released on demand into the surrounding flow. In addition, we developed an imaging and analysis method to quantify all three components of sphere rotation in addition to translation.  Dedicated experiments were performed to determine particle friction and restitution coefficients needed as inputs for numerical simulations.  Separately, extensive experiments were performed on particles released into turbulent boundary layer flows in controlled fashion to understand the effects of mean shear, gravity, and turbulent eddy scales on particle lift off, translation, and rotation.  The experiments demonstrated that fluid-based lift forces were strongly dependent on wall proximity. By contrast, fluid-based torque was insufficient to generate significant sphere rotation unless aided by wall-friction forces. Additional experiments that tracked both the particle and surrounding fluid velocity field showed that coherent structures in the turbulent flow strongly affected all components of particle translational velocity.

On the numerical side, a novel energy-conserving overset grid method for unstructured grids was developed to enable simulations that resolved all of the turbulent fluid scales as well as details of the stresses on particles moving within turbulent boundary layers.  The method is transformative in that it is designed to allow easy scale up to various complex flow problems that require the most advanced supercomputers.  In the current investigation, the method enabled resolution of small-scale friction and collision interactions between individual particles and between particles and bounding surfaces. The numerical method was applied to investigate particle propagation down inclined planes under conditions matching the particle friction experiments.  It was also applied in turbulent channel flow in simulations including many spherical particles.  Together, the experiments and simulations allowed evaluation of the importance of unsteady effects, particle-wall friction forces, inter-particle lubrication effects, and dipole-scale collision effects. 

Broader Impacts:

The knowledge gained about particle interactive effects, experimental methodologies and simulation methodologies can be used to understand and model not only liquid flows with solid particles, but also liquid or gas flows carrying discrete drops, bubbles, or small organisms, and gas flows with particles. Thus, more accurate predictive capabilities for particle-laden flows will lead to improved understanding of particle, pollutant, and nutrient transport and species population dynamics in aquatic and atmospheric environments, more efficient processes in energy production and conversion, and more efficient transport and processing of materials.  In addition, the numerical method can be employed to resolve fine scales in biomedical problems, including tracking, inhalation and deposition of droplets and aerosols, such as those associated with Coronaviruses. Further, the unstructured overset computational methodology enables high-fidelity simulation of a wide range of additional problems involving moving bodies or vehicles with complex surfaces and their interactions with the surrounding fluid flow.  Similarly, the experimental methodology can be extended and employed across problems requiring simultaneous tracking of surface motions and surrounding fluid motion.

Multiple graduate students were trained on this project, and multiple undergraduates participated in the research through REU supplements and the UM UROP program. Post-doctoral researchers made significant contributions to the experimental and numerical methods developed.  The PIs and their teams also worked directly each summer with middle school students attending the Minnesota Aviation Career Education (ACE) Camp. Additional outreach activities included mentoring female high school students considering engineering careers, giving lab tours to groups of students from junior high to undergrad level, and participating on mentoring panels for women and minority scholars from undergraduate to tenure-track level.

POR.POR_COPY_TXT: Turbulent flows containing discrete particles occur in many processes related to Grand Challenges in climate prediction, energy production, and environmental conservation. These flows are difficult to understand and predict due to the wide range of turbulence length scales in the carrier fluid as well as the complex physics that occurs on the scale of the particle diameter. The goal of the proposed research was to advance both experimental and simulation capabilities to resolve key particle interactive effects in turbulent wall-bounded flows. Key outcomes of the investigation included development of novel experimental and simulation techniques that allowed investigation of these detailed effects. In addition, the techniques were employed to elucidate surprising aspects of the particle dynamics. Intellectual Merit: On the experimental side, we developed a method to fabricate magnetic, spherical particles of controlled density that could be held in place on a bounding surface and released on demand into the surrounding flow. In addition, we developed an imaging and analysis method to quantify all three components of sphere rotation in addition to translation. Dedicated experiments were performed to determine particle friction and restitution coefficients needed as inputs for numerical simulations. Separately, extensive experiments were performed on particles released into turbulent boundary layer flows in controlled fashion to understand the effects of mean shear, gravity, and turbulent eddy scales on particle lift off, translation, and rotation. The experiments demonstrated that fluid-based lift forces were strongly dependent on wall proximity. By contrast, fluid-based torque was insufficient to generate significant sphere rotation unless aided by wall-friction forces. Additional experiments that tracked both the particle and surrounding fluid velocity field showed that coherent structures in the turbulent flow strongly affected all components of particle translational velocity. On the numerical side, a novel energy-conserving overset grid method for unstructured grids was developed to enable simulations that resolved all of the turbulent fluid scales as well as details of the stresses on particles moving within turbulent boundary layers. The method is transformative in that it is designed to allow easy scale up to various complex flow problems that require the most advanced supercomputers. In the current investigation, the method enabled resolution of small-scale friction and collision interactions between individual particles and between particles and bounding surfaces. The numerical method was applied to investigate particle propagation down inclined planes under conditions matching the particle friction experiments. It was also applied in turbulent channel flow in simulations including many spherical particles. Together, the experiments and simulations allowed evaluation of the importance of unsteady effects, particle-wall friction forces, inter-particle lubrication effects, and dipole-scale collision effects. Broader Impacts: The knowledge gained about particle interactive effects, experimental methodologies and simulation methodologies can be used to understand and model not only liquid flows with solid particles, but also liquid or gas flows carrying discrete drops, bubbles, or small organisms, and gas flows with particles. Thus, more accurate predictive capabilities for particle-laden flows will lead to improved understanding of particle, pollutant, and nutrient transport and species population dynamics in aquatic and atmospheric environments, more efficient processes in energy production and conversion, and more efficient transport and processing of materials. In addition, the numerical method can be employed to resolve fine scales in biomedical problems, including tracking, inhalation and deposition of droplets and aerosols, such as those associated with Coronaviruses. Further, the unstructured overset computational methodology enables high-fidelity simulation of a wide range of additional problems involving moving bodies or vehicles with complex surfaces and their interactions with the surrounding fluid flow. Similarly, the experimental methodology can be extended and employed across problems requiring simultaneous tracking of surface motions and surrounding fluid motion. Multiple graduate students were trained on this project, and multiple undergraduates participated in the research through REU supplements and the UM UROP program. Post-doctoral researchers made significant contributions to the experimental and numerical methods developed. The PIs and their teams also worked directly each summer with middle school students attending the Minnesota Aviation Career Education (ACE) Camp. Additional outreach activities included mentoring female high school students considering engineering careers, giving lab tours to groups of students from junior high to undergrad level, and participating on mentoring panels for women and minority scholars from undergraduate to tenure-track level.
